claims: As a result, we provide a comprehensive structural genomics and interactomics road-maps of 2019-nCoV and use these information to infer the possible functional differences and similarities with the related SARS coronavirus
Using an integrated bioinformatics approach, we provide a comprehensive structural genomics and interactomics analysis of the Wuhan 2019-nCov virus

We found that the mutated residues tend to locate on the protein’s surface, supporting the previous observations in other families of RNA viruses that the core residues of viral proteins are more conserved than the surface residues [48, 56, 57]

We found that all protein binding sites of non-structural proteins involving in the intra-viral heteromeric complexes, wNSP7-wNsp8-wNsp12, wNsp10-wNsp14, and wNsp10-wNsp16, are either fully conserved or allow at most one mutation on the periphery of the binding region, in spite of the fact that each proteins had multiple mutations on their surfaces (Fig. 4A, see Suppl

We find that two interactions, with mAb 396 [58] and mAb 80R [59], are likely to be disrupted due to the heavily mutated binding sites while another one, Ab G2 [60], is likely to be disrupted due to a novel insert into the sequence of wS
For each 2019-nCoV protein in a protein-protein interaction complex, we identify all binding residues that constitute its protein-binding site
key_statements: A vaccine for Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), another coronavirus that emerged in 2012, was patented in 2019, with the Phase I trials introduced in the same year [7, 8]

In the past two decades, a massive amount of work has been done to understand the molecular basis of the coronavirus infection and evolution, develop effective treatment in forms of both vaccines and antiviral drugs, and propose efficient measures for viral detection and prevention [9-18]

Can it be facilitated? The answer lies in the use of the modern bioinformatics methods that can drastically streamline knowledge discovery by quickly providing the important insights about possible molecular mechanisms behind the infection, pinpointing the likely protein targets for the antiviral treatments, and predicting the efficacy of the existing antivirals developed for other coronaviruses

In addition to the global structural genomics initiatives focusing on determining the 3D structures of proteins on a genome scale [34] and specific efforts on rapid structural characterization of proteins in emerging viruses [35-38], multiple works have used comparative modeling to predict the structures of protein-protein interaction complexes [39-41], facilitating structure-based drug discovery [33, 42, 43], inferring protein functions [44], determining the macromolecular interaction network [45-47], and providing molecular insights into viral evolution [48-50]

The structural information on the individual 2019-nCov proteins and their interactions with each other and with the human proteins allows to accurately determine the putative functional sites. These functional sites, combined with the evolutionary sequence analysis of 2019-nCov as well as the closely related human severe acute respiratory syndrome and bat coronavirus proteomes, provide us with a structure-based view of the evolutionary diversity of 2019-nCov, allow to estimate how similar the functioning of 2019-nCov virus is when compared with severe acute respiratory syndrome, and forecast how likely the antibodies and candidate ligands that are efficient in inhibiting the severe acute respiratory syndrome functions will be efficient in doing the same for 2019-nCov

The recently sequenced genomes of 2019-nCoV strains combined with the comparative analysis of the severe acute respiratory syndrome genome organization and transcription allowed to determine the tentative list of gene products [51]

Comparative analysis of 2019-nCoV proteins with the evolutionary related coronavirus proteins reveals unevenly distributed large genomic insertions Searching against UniProt database [52] resulted in matches for the polyprotein, all four structural proteins, and six ORFs referred to as accessory proteins
The closest protein matches from UniProt shared sequence identity with the related 2019-nCoV proteins as high as 91% and as low as 57% (Supl

Perhaps the most profound differences lie in the sequences of the multi-domain protein wNsp3 and surface protein wS: our analysis revealed that compared to the related coronavirus proteins (multiple sequence alignments for both proteins can be found in Suppl

Being significantly more diverse than the other three structural proteins, wS was found to have 4 inserts (4-6 res.) that seemed unique to 2019-nCoV and two additional inserts shared with human severe acute respiratory syndrome proteins (Suppl

Our search resulted in three new homologs of ORF8 from three different isolates of bat severe acute respiratory syndrome-like coronavirus: bat-SL-CoVZC45 (GenBank ID: MG772933, collected in 2017), bat-SL-CoVZXC21 (GenBank ID: MG772934, collected in 2015), and RaTG13 (GenBank ID: MN996532, collected in 2013) that shared a striking similarity with wORF8, unseen in other strains before: the sequence identities between each of these three homologs and wORF8 ranged between the 94 and 95%

Further analysis showed that the proteomes of these isolates shared even higher sequence identity with the other proteins of 2019-nCoV: from 88.4% to 100% for 2015 and 2017 isolates, and even higher 97.4%-100% for the 2013 isolate (Supl
Neither of the two isolate had the large insert between the tow domain of wNsp3 of wORF1ab described above

The main difference between 2019-nCoV and 2013 isolate is the lack of Orf10 in the latter: while genomic sequences of both 2015 and 2017 isolates can be translated into a protein product that shares 97.4% of sequence identity (Supl
A previously identified transmembrane domain of severe acute respiratory syndrome Nsp3 was mapped to the sequence of wNsp3, but could not be modeled due to the lack of a template structure

We found that the mutated residues tend to locate on the protein’s surface, supporting the previous observations in other families of RNA viruses that the core residues of viral proteins are more conserved than the surface residues [48, 56, 57]

We found that all protein binding sites of non-structural proteins involving in the intra-viral heteromeric complexes, wNSP7-wNsp8-wNsp12, wNsp10-wNsp14, and wNsp10-wNsp16, are either fully conserved or allow at most one mutation on the periphery of the binding region, in spite of the fact that each proteins had multiple mutations on their surfaces (Fig. 4A, see Suppl
Three of the novel inserts are located in the first NTD domain, while the fourth one is located immediately before the S2 cleavage site and inside the homo-trimerization interaction interface
The NTD domain has been considered a target of another antibody Ab G2 previously shown to work in Middle East respiratory syndrome [60]

The analysis of seven ligand binding sites for multiple candidate inhibitors previously identified for four proteins in severe acute respiratory syndrome and Middle East respiratory syndrome showed that many of the LBS were intact in the corresponding 2019-nCoV proteins (Fig. D, see Suppl
The network analysis of all three networks showed that unifying the intra-viral and virus-host networks reduces the number of components in the SARSCoV-Host interactome (Table 2)

NSP8 is the other major hub and interacts with other replicase proteins, including two other hubs, i.e. NSP7 and NSP 12, which together play a crucial role in replication [63]. Another crucial non-structural protein is NSP1, present in the 2019-nCoV, which is known to be a primary disruptor of innate immunity
The host interaction partners of NSP1 modulate the Calcineurin/NFAT pathway that plays an important role in immune cell activation [64]
Overexpression of NSP1 is associated with immunopathogenecity and long-term cytokine dysregulation as observed in severe severe acute respiratory syndrome cases

The same interaction is inferred from structural modeling in 2019-nCoV between wS and angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, but might be disrupted due to a substantial number of mutations in the receptor binding site of wS while another recent study proposed that the interaction will be preserved [65]

Similar to severe acute respiratory syndrome-CoV [66], wS protein in 2019-nCoV is expected to interact with type II transmembrane protease (TMPRSS2) [67] and is likely to be involved in inhibition of antibody-mediated neutralization

WS remains the important target for vaccines and drugs previously evaluated in severe acute respiratory syndrome and Middle East respiratory syndrome while a neutralizing antibody targeting the wS protein could provide passive immunity [68]

There are 7 interactions from severe acute respiratory syndrome-CoV determined from structural characterization of the protein complexes that are predicted to be either conserved or potentially disrupted in 2019-nCoV

We structurally modeled interactions between the 2019-nCoV wS protein and three human monoclonal antibodies that were previously studied in severe acute respiratory syndrome-CoV for immunotherapy and mapped the information about the evolutionary conserved and diverse surface residues

By providing a comparative analysis between the new virus and its closest relatives from the perspective of protein- and ligand-binding, we hope to help experimental scientists in their understanding of the molecular mechanisms implicated in the infection by the new coronavirus as well as in the process of vaccine development and antiviral drug discovery

The presence of the four novel inserts and one highly variable region of the surface protein wS and the analysis of this large-scale sequence changes with respect to intra-viral and viral-host interaction leads us to conclude that these inserts might have structural impact on the homo-trimeric form of the protein as well as the impact on the functions carried out by NTD domain

The whole structures of the multi-domain proteins wN and wNsp3 could be resolved by integrating individual models with the lower-resolution but whole-protein covering techniques such as cryogenic electron microscopy (CryoEM)
The evolutionary analysis of the protein and ligand-binding sites mapped on the surfaces of 2019-nCoV may provide new insights into the virus functioning and its future treatment

The 100% or near 100% evolutionary conservation of the protein binding sites on the surfaces of nonstructural proteins wNsp7, wNsp8, wNsp10, wNsp12, wNsp14, and wNsp16 that correspond to the intra-viral interactions for three complexes is consistent with our previous observations that the intra-viral interactions are significantly more conserved than viral-host interactions [48, 49, 69]

The near-perfect conservation of the human ubiquitin-aldehyde protein binding site on the surface of wNsp3 is rather intriguing suggesting the critical role of this interaction in the functioning of severe acute respiratory syndrome-like coronaviruses

The conservation of the ligand bind sites for many putative inhibitors previously developed for severe acute respiratory syndrome and Middle East respiratory syndrome suggests the development of antiviral drugs as a promising direction for addressing this new global health threat

The information on the evolutionary differences and conservations observed between the protein sequences of 2019-nCoV and the related coronaviruses and extracted from the above protein sequence alignments will mapped onto the structural models of the 2019-nCoV proteins to determine if the protein- and ligand-binding site are functionally conserved

The polyprotein wORF1ab was first split into 16 putative proteins based on its alignment with the human severe acute respiratory syndrome polyprotein, with each protein independently searched against Protein Data Bank

Once all ligand binding sites residues are identified for a related coronavirus, the residues are mapped onto the surface of the related 2019-nCoV protein using a structural alignment between the two proteins, which puts into a one-to-one correspondence residues from both proteins
